newsitem.title: GERMANY: German DAX index blasted by Greenspan comments.
newsitem.headline: German DAX index blasted by Greenspan comments.

text.p: German shares hit intraday lows in post-bourse electronic trade on Thursday after U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan signalled that the central bank was inching towards raising interest rates.
The IBIS DAX index ended at 3,247.03 points, down 58.69 points or 1.78 percent, having earlier fallen 2.21 percent to 3,232.57 points after the Greenspan comments.
In prepared testimony to Congress' Joint Economic Committee, Greenspan said the economy retains a "great deal of vigor" and the jobs market is strong.

The central bank's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee meets on Tuesday to consider raising short-term rates for the first time in over two years. The dollar went higher against the mark on the news.
Earlier the DAX-30 index ended at 3,264.67 points, down 1.55 percent.
Deutsche Telekom was the heaviest-traded stock in afternoon trade, ending the day up 50 pfennigs at 36.70 marks.

"Everyone is reckoning on a rate increase in the U.S. next week. But I think what we are seeing at the moment could best be described as a healthy consolidation, and I don't think a serious correction is on the cards," he added.

Sentiment was also muted in advance of Friday's triple-witching options expiry. March DAX DTB futures, due to expire then, fell 65 points to 3,244 points, which had a negative effect on the cash market.

The big corporate news of the day was the return to trade of steel/engineering groups Thyssen AG and Krupp-Hoesch after two days of suspension related to Krupp's attempts to produce a merger of their steel businesses.
Krupp ended up 15.56 percent at 312 marks, while Thyssen ended up 8.59 percent at 374.10 marks, making them two of the biggest gainers in afternoon IBIS trade.
Drugs group Schering AG climbed early on amid continued positive reaction to its move on Wednesday to raise its forecast for 1997 results.
However it was the subject of profit-taking later on and ended down 80 pfennigs at 161.50 marks.
Other shares in the pharmaceutical/drugs sector performed well in the afternoon, with Gehe ending up one mark, 0.83 percent.
Banks also took a hammering later on, with Deutsche Bank ending down 3.44 percent, or 3.11 marks at 87.40 marks, while carmaker Volkswagen ended down 33.90 marks, or 3.74 percent, at 872 marks.
The banks also took a hammering later on, with Deutsche down 3.11 marks at 87.40 marks and Commerzbank down 76 pfennigs at 45.15 marks.
